intro.para: In this section we use the ordering structure on the real number system to define the absolute value operation. We then establish its basic properties.

def.caption: Absolute value operation on \RNr

info.caption: Explanation
info.para: Read this as: ‘The absolute value of x is defined to be x if 0 is less than or equal to x, and is defined to be negative x if x is less than or equal to 0.

info.caption: Explanation
info.para: This definition makes sense because we know from the totality property of the ordering on \RNr that one of the two statements ‘0\leq x’ and ‘x\leq 0’ always applies. Moreover, we proved that, if x\leq 0, then 0\leq -x. So 0\leq \Abs{x} always.

info.caption: Comment
info.para: Notice that we do not require a new assumption in the form of an axiom to introduce the absolute value of a real number. Rather this is a construction which can be performed based on axioms and properties discussed earlier.
